Sec. 46-66. - Title. (a) The ordinance codified in this division is adopted by the City Council of St. Marys, Georgia, pursuant to Article IX, Section II, Paragraph I of the Constitution of Georgia (1983), and shall be referred to as the "St. Marys Noise Control Ordinance." (b) The St. Marys City Council has determined that noise is a major source of environmental pollution which represents a threat to the serenity and quality of life in the City of St. Marys and that noise exposure may be a cause of adverse physiological and psychological effects as well as economic loss. It is the intention of this division to limit noise in housing areas and other noise sensitive urban areas. (Ord. No. 2013-022 , 7-1-13) Sec. 46-67. - Definitions. The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this division, unless otherwise specifically stated: A-weighted sound level shall mean the sound pressure level as measured in decibels (dB) on a sound level meter using the A-weighting network. This level is designated dB(A) or dBA. City shall mean the City of St. Marys, its elected and appointed officials and staff. Construction means any site preparation, assembly, erection, substantial repair, alteration or similar action, for or on public or private rights-of-way, structures, utilities or similar property. Decibel (dB) means a logarithmic and dimensionless unit of measure used in describing the relative loudness or level of sound. Demolition. Any dismantling, intentional destruction or removal of structures, utilities, public or private rights-of-way surfaces, or similar property. Emergency means any occurrence or set of circumstances involving actual or imminent physical or psychological trauma or property damage which demands immediate action. Emergency work is work made necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a public calamity or work required to protect persons or property from an imminent exposure to danger. Noise disturbance means any sound which endangers or injures the welfare, safety or health of human beings, or disturbs a reasonable person of normal sensitivities, or devalues or injures personal or real property. Noise-sensitive activities means any activities which should be conducted under conditions of exceptional quiet, including but not limited to: operation of schools and day care centers; libraries; cemeteries; nursing and convalescent homes; hospitals and medical clinics; and churches. Person. Any individual, partnership, firm, association, joint venture, public or private corporation, trust, estate, commission, board, public or private institution, utility, operative, state agency, municipality, or other political subdivisions of this state, any interstate body, or any other legal entity. Plainly audible shall mean any sound emanating from the specific sound-producing sources set forth herein which can be heard from the locations set forth herein, using the following sound measurement standards: measurement shall be either by sound meter; or by the auditory senses of a person standing at a distance no less than the required minimum distance from the source of the sound. For music and other noise, words and phrases need not be discernible. For music and other noise, bass reverberations are included. Plainly audible within an adjoining residential dwelling shall mean any sound emanating from the specific sound-producing sources set forth herein which can be heard inside a residential dwelling at the locations set forth herein, using the following sound measurement standards: measurement shall be by sound meter; or the auditory senses of a person standing within any living area of a residential dwelling at a distance of at least five feet from the exterior wall of the residential dwelling with all exterior doors and windows closed. For music and other noise, words and phrases need not be discernible. For music and other noise, bass and mega-bass reverberations are included. Powered model vehicle. Any self-propelled airborne, waterborne, or landborne model plane, vessel, or vehicle which is not designed to carry persons, including, but not limited to, any model airplane, boat, car or rocket. Public right-of-way means any street, avenue, highway, lane or similar place which is owned or controlled by a governmental entity. Public space means any real property including any structure thereon which is owned or controlled by a governmental entity. Real property boundary. An imaginary line along the ground surface, and its vertical extension, which separates real property owned or occupied by one person from that owned or occupied by another person, including walls, ceilings and floors which separate the units in a multi-occupancy building. Receiving land use means the use or occupancy of the real property which receives the transmission of sound. Sound level means the quantity in decibels measured with an instrument that measures sound in decibels (dB). Times means Eastern Standard Time or daylight saving time as observed in the state. Zoning districts shall mean those districts established by Zoning Ordinance No. 110 of the City of St. Marys. (Ord. No. 2013-022 , 7-1-13) Sec. 46-68. - Exceptions. The provisions of this division shall not apply to the following: (1) Emission of sound for the purpose of alerting people to the existence of danger; (2) Emission of sound in the performance of emergency work; (3) Rail and air transportation and/or public transportation vehicles; (4) Church or clock carillons, bells or chimes; (5) Agricultural activities limited to the raising of crops but exclusive of those involving the ownership or possession of animals or birds as stated in section 46-74; (6) Fireworks or fireworks displays for which a permit has been issued by the city; (7) Alarms, as defined in the alarm control ordinance of the city, which are properly maintained in accordance with that ordinance; (8) Sound volumes produced by radio, tape player, or other mechanical sound-making device or instrument from within a moving motor vehicle on a street or highway, which sound is controlled by O.C.G.A. § 40-6-14. O.C.G.A. § 40-6-14 makes it unlawful for any person operating or occupying a motor vehicle on a street or highway to operate or amplify the sound produced by a mechanical sound-making device from within the motor vehicle so that the sound is plainly audible at a distance of 100 feet or more from any parked motor vehicle; (9) The emission of sound in the discharge of weapons at a firing range issued a permit by the city. (Ord. No. 2013-022 , 7-1-13) Sec. 46-69. - Noise disturbance prohibited. (a) No person shall make, continue or cause to be made or continued any noise disturbance or noise in excess of the limits for such noise established in this section. (b) With the exception of sound levels elsewhere specifically authorized by this division, Table One sets forth the maximum permissible sound levels allowed at or within the real property boundary of a receiving land use. Any activity or use that produces a sound in excess of such noise levels for the receiving land use shall be deemed a "noise disturbance" and in violation of this division. (c) The measurement of sound or noise shall be made with a sound level meter in dB. The measurement of all sound levels shall be made as close to the property line of the receiving land as is practical. The measurement period shall not be less than five minutes, and the sound level measured shall not exceed the sound levels set forth in the included table more than ten percent of the time during any measurement period. The chief of police shall formulate, in accordance with recognized sound testing standards, rules and regulations describing how measurement of sound levels will be made. TABLE ONE
(d) The provisions of this section shall not apply to the operation of the following domestic power tools or equipment between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m.: (1) Electrical power tools; (2) Motor-powered, muffler-equipped lawn, garden and tree trimming equipment. (Ord. No. 2013-022 , 7-1-13) Sec. 46-70. - Specific activities prohibited. (a) Sales by hawking or barking. No person shall offer for sale or sell anything by shouting or outcry within any residential area. (b) Loading and unloading. No person shall load, unload, open, close or handle boxes, crates, containers, building material, refuse, garbage cans, dumpsters, motor vehicles, or similar objects between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following day as to create a noise disturbance across a residential real property boundary line. (c) Vehicle or motor boat repair and testing. No person shall repair, rebuild, modify or test any motor vehicle, motorcycle or motorboat in such a manner as to create a noise disturbance across a residential real property boundary or within a noise sensitive zone. (d) Power model vehicles. No person shall operate or permit the operation of a powered model vehicle in a public or private space out-of-doors in such a manner as to create a noise disturbance across a residential real property boundary or within a noise sensitive zone or within 150 feet of a residential real property boundary or during the hours from 9:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. (e) Musical instruments and similar devices. No person shall operate, play or permit the operation or playing of any drum, musical instrument or similar device which produces sound in a manner as to create a noise disturbance across a residential real property boundary, subject to other provisions of this division. (f) Recreational motorized vehicles. No person shall operate or permit the operation of any recreational motorized vehicle, motorcycle, moped, dune buggy or any other type of motorized vehicle that exceeds the limits set forth in Table One of this division off the public right-of-way in any residential or noise sensitive area. This section shall apply to all motorized vehicles noted above, whether or not duly licensed and registered. (Ord. No. 2013-022 , 7-1-13) Sec. 46-71. - Regulation of sound equipment and sound amplifying equipment. (a) Except as hereafter provided, no person shall use, operate or cause to be used or operated, the following devices including, but not limited to, any radio, record player, tape deck or player, loud speaker, amplifier, sound track or other device for producing, reproducing, or amplifying sounds, hereinafter referred to as "sound equipment", upon the public streets or in any building or upon any premises, public or private, so as to produce a noise disturbance. Provided, however; the following activities, when authorized by the city in writing, may use sound equipment which produces a sound not to exceed 90 dBA's when measured at a distance of 50 feet from such equipment: (1) Public health and safety purposes. (2) Fairs, carnivals, permitted assemblies and similar activities. (3) Parades, processions, excursions and associated festivities. (4) Outdoor concerts and theatrical performances. (5) Outdoor neighborhood functions such as lawn and pool parties, street dances and similar activities. (6) Civic and religious celebrations. (7) Recreational and athletic activities. (b) Where the receiving land is residential such equipment may be used only from 9:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. (c) Except for activities for which a permit has been issued by the city under this section, no person shall so operate, play or permit the operation or playing of any radio, television, tape player, compact disc player or phonograph or similar device so as to: (1) Create a noise disturbance across a residential real property boundary line. Bars, taverns, lounges, nightclubs, dance halls, game rooms and similar activities which produce a noise that is plainly audible beyond the premises shall be deemed a noise disturbance in violation of this division. (2) Create a noise which is plainly audible at a distance of 25 feet from a private motor vehicle, when such device is operated in or on a public right-of-way or public space. (3) Create a noise which is plainly audible at a distance of 25 feet in or on any public space. (d) Sound equipment permitted. Except as hereafter provided, no person shall use, operate, or cause to be used or operated any radio, record player, tape deck or player, loudspeaker, amplifier, sound track or other device for producing, reproducing or amplifying sounds, hereinafter referred to as "sound equipment" upon the public streets or upon any private or public premises so as to produce a noise disturbance. However, noise emanating from activities upon public property from which the city has issued any necessary permit or in which the city is a sponsor shall be exempt. (e) Commercial advertising, sound equipment prohibited. No sound equipment shall be permitted to be used on public streets or public places, or in any building or upon any premises if the sound therefrom may be plainly audible from any public street or public place when any such use is for commercial advertising purposes or for any purpose of attracting attention of the public to any structure or building for monetary gain. (f) Party noise. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons in charge of a party or other social event that occurs on any private property to allow that party or social event to produce noise in such a manner that such noise is plainly audible at a distance of 100 feet or more from the source of the noises or sounds between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. (Ord. No. 2013-022 , 7-1-13) Sec. 46-72. - Construction work. No person shall operate or permit the operation of any tools or equipment in construction, demolition or maintenance work: (1) Between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. which creates a noise disturbance across a residential real property boundary or within a noise sensitive area. (2) Any noise disturbance which creates a noise across a real property boundary, for the purpose of this subsection, a sound level at or across the real property boundary in excess of 85 dBA shall be deemed a noise disturbance. (3) The provisions of this section shall not apply to: a. Emergency work or repair work performed by or for governmental entities or public service utilities. b. The use of domestic power tools or equipment as set forth above. (Ord. No. 2013-022 , 7-1-13) Sec. 46-73. - Motorized vehicles. (a) No person shall operate the engine providing motive power, or an auxiliary engine, of a motor vehicle with a manufacturer's gross vehicle weight rating of 1,000 pounds or more for a consecutive period longer than 20 minutes while such vehicle is standing and located within 150 feet of property zoned and used for residential purposes except where such vehicle is standing within a completely enclosed structure. This section shall not apply to delivery or pickup vehicles that require the operation of the engine to unload or load their vending loads. (b) No person shall drive or move or cause or knowingly permit to be driven or moved, a motor vehicle or combination of vehicles at any time in such a manner as to exceed the noise limits in Table Two for the category or motor vehicle shown below. Noise shall be measured at a distance of at least 25 feet from the near side of the nearest land(s) being monitored and at a height of at least four feet above the immediate surrounding surface. TABLE TWO
(c) This section shall apply to the total noise from a vehicle or combination of vehicles and shall not be construed as limiting or precluding the enforcement of any other provisions of this chapter relating to motor vehicle mufflers for noise control. (d) No person shall operate or cause to be operated any motor vehicle unless the exhaust system of such vehicle is: (1) Free from defects which affect sound reduction. (2) Equipped with a muffler or other noise dissipation device. (3) Not equipped with any cut-out, by-pass or similar device. (4) Not equipped with after sale equipment designed to modify (increase) the sound over that of the factory installed equipment. (Ord. No. 2013-022 , 7-1-13) Sec. 46-74. - Animal and bird noise. (a) No person shall own, possess or harbor any animal or bird which howls, barks, or emits audible sounds that are unreasonably loud or disturbing and which are of such character, intensity, and duration as to disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood. (b) For the purposes of this section, "barking dog" shall mean a dog that barks, bays, cries, howls or makes any other noise to the disturbance of any person at any time of day or night regardless of whether the dog is physically situated in or upon private property; provided, however, that a dog shall not be deemed a "barking dog" for the purposes of this division, if at the time the dog is barking or making any other noise, a person is trespassing or threatening to trespass upon private property in or upon which the dog is situated or close proximity thereto, or for any other cause which teased or provoked the dog. (Ord. No. 2013-022 , 7-1-13) Sec. 46-75. - Variances. Variance permit. A variance permit to cause or create a noise at sound levels which would otherwise be in violation of this division may be granted by the city council upon recommendation by the chief of police if: (1) Additional time is necessary for the applicant to alter or modify the activity in order to comply with the provisions of this division; or (2) The activity, operation or noise source will be of a temporary duration and cannot be done in a manner that would comply with the provisions of this division; and (3) No reasonable alternative is available to the applicant. (Ord. No. 2013-022 , 7-1-13) Sec. 46-76. - Conditions for permits. (a) Any permit granted pursuant to this section shall contain therein all conditions placed upon the holder of the permit as conditions to the permit being granted, including but not limited to, the effective date, time of day, location, sound level limit or equipment limitation. Application for such a permit shall be made in writing in such form as is acceptable to the city through the city manager's office. (b) Notwithstanding the provisions of this division concerning mechanical sound-making devices, the chief of police has the discretion to grant written permission authorizing the use of mechanical sound-making devices at such a volume and in such a manner so as to create, or cause to be created, noises or sounds which are plainly audible at a distance of 1,000 feet from the source of the noise or sound between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. Such written authorization may be given for the following: (1) Public health and safety purposes; (2) Fairs, carnivals and similar activities; (3) Parades, processions, excursions and associated festivities; (4) Outdoor concerts and theatrical performances; (5) Outdoor neighborhood functions such as lawn and pool parties, street dances and similar activities; (6) Civic and religious celebrations; (7) Recreational and athletic activities. In determining whether to grant such permission, the chief of police should consider the following factors: a. Level or volume, duration, and types of the proposed noises or sounds; b. Source or nature of the noise or sounds (i.e., musical instruments, amplified music, etc.); c. Level and intensity of any background noise; d. Proximity of sleeping facilities or quiet zones (i.e., hospitals and hotels); e. Zoning classification of the area; f. Population density of the area; g. Whether the noise is recurrent, intermittent, or constant; and h. Whether the applicant or location has previously violated the ordinance codified in this division. (Ord. No. 2013-022 , 7-1-13) Sec. 46-77. - Administration, appeals and penalties. (a) The chief of police shall implement, administer and enforce the provisions of this division and shall issue orders requiring the abatement of all violations and the revocation of permits issued. (b) Each and every day a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. Each and every violation of this division, including separate violations on the same day, shall be deemed a separate offense. (c) Any person in violation of this division, upon conviction, shall be guilty of an ordinance violation punishable by a warning for the first offense and thereafter punishable by a fine of at least $500.00, but not to exceed $1,500.00; or by imprisonment of at least 24 hours, not to exceed 60 days, or both. Any person who violates this division may be subject to immediate arrest. The imposition of a penalty under the provisions of this section shall not prevent the revocation of any permit issued pursuant to this division. (Ord. No. 2013-022 , 7-1-13) Sec. 46-78. - Provisions of this division declared to be minimum requirements. (a) In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this division shall be held to be minimum requirements, adopted for the promotion of public health, safety, morals, or general welfare. Wherever the requirements of this division are at variance with the requirements of the lawfully adopted rules, regulations, or ordinances of the City of St. Marys, Camden County, State of Georgia, and the United States of America, the most restrictive or that imposing the higher standards shall govern. (b) The city shall not approve any request for any subdivision, special use, variance, building permit or other permit/license request that is not in compliance with this division, in opposition to any currently effective, legally adopted deed restriction and/or covenants which apply to the property for which the request is made. (c) The city is not required to enforce and will not enforce any deed restrictions, covenants or similar private legal agreements concerning the use of land in the city. (d) In the event any portion of this division shall be declared or adjudged invalid or unconstitutional, it is the intention of the city council of the city that such adjudication shall in no manner affect the other sections, sentences, clauses, or phrases of this division which shall remain in full force and effect, as if the invalid or unconstitutional section, sentence, clause, or phrase were not originally a part of the division.
