If the appeal is filed, the city council shall receive a report and recommendation thereon from the planning commission and shall hold a public hearing on the appeal. In exercising the above powers, the city council may reverse, affirm or modify the orders or requirements, and to that end shall have the powers of the officer from whom the appeal is taken and may issue the necessary permit. Sec. 86-165. - Court review of city council action. Any person(s) aggrieved by any decision of the city council may make an appeal to the superior court. Said appeals to the superior court shall be as defined in O.C.G.A. 5-4-3. The appeal must be made to the superior court within 30 days after the city council decision otherwise the decision of city council is final.

div.head: Chapter 87 - ST. MARYS ENTERPRISE ZONE
div.p: Sec. 87-1. - Satisfaction of criteria. In the geographic area known as the St. Marys Enterprise Zone and as herein described in Exhibit A, a copy of which is attached to Ordinance No. 2013-029 and hereby incorporated by reference, in compiiance with O.C.G.A. § 36-88-6 and as subsequently amended, that the city finds the area meets the qualification of the Act by meeting the following criteria: (1) Pervasive poverty. The enterprise zone is located in portions of Census Tract 106.011 and 106.013. Within these two census block groups, the percent of the total population below the poverty level is 18.49 and 22.82, according to the Georgia Department of Community Affairs American Community Survey, 2006-2010 Poverty Estimate. 2. Unemployment. Unemployment shall be evidenced by significant job dislocation was experienced at 1000 Osborne Street with the closure of Durango Paper Company, formerly known as Gilman Paper Company. The City of St. Marys has suffered greatly with the close of the mill. Countless supporting businesses in St. Marys including hardware stores, restaurants, retail establishments, and service companies have closed as a result of mill's closure. At the time of the mill's closure 850 full-time jobs were lost. (3) General distress. The City of St. Marys Enterprise Zone area suffers from general distress and adverse conditions as evidenced by abandoned or dilapidated structures, deteriorated infrastructure, and substantial population decline. The nominated area, once primarily a center of paper manufacturing in nature, shows significant loss of business with a need for new employment opportunities to utilize the existing vacancies. Consequently, the area shows evidence of creeping blighted conditions that although scattered throughout the area, potentially pose a threat of future disinvestments creating a diminishing tax base within the area. Although most areas in St. Marys have increased or maintained their population, the population of the distressed sites has decreased as witnessed by the vacant storefronts. (4) Underdevelopment. The Planning and Development Department for the City of St. Marys has amassed data showing that over the past five years there have been fewer building permits and land disturbance permits issued in the geographic area known as the St. Marys Enterprise Zone, and that the department collects less development fees, capital recovery fees, and other similar fees from the area as compared to other areas of the city. The City of St. Marys Planning Department has also amassed data that shows that there are less business license fees collected and less business licenses issued within the nominated area than within the local governing body's jurisdiction overall. (Ord. No. 2013-024 , 10-21-13) Sec. 87-2. - Establishment of St. Marys Enterprise Zone. In order to alleviate the above conditions the council hereby designates the area described in Exhibit A, attached to Ordinance No. 2013-029 and incorporated by reference herein, as an enterprise zone to be known as the "St. Marys Enterprise Zone". (Ord. No. 2013-024 , 10-21-13) Sec. 87-3. - Abatement of ad valorem taxes. The council exempts any qualifying business enterprise or qualifying service enterprise as defined in O.C.G.A. § 36-88-3 from municipal ad valorem property taxes (excluding property taxes imposed by school districts) in an amount not to exceed those set forth in O.C.G.A. § 36-88-8(a), as may be subsequently amended, provided said qualifying business or service enterprises meet the qualifying criteria outlined in O.C.G.A. § 36-88-4 and in accordance with the following schedule: (1) One hundred percent abatement of post assessed rehabilitation property taxes shall be exempt for the first five years. (2) Eighty percent of post assessed rehabilitation property taxes will be exempt for year six. (3) Sixty percent of post assessed rehabilitation property taxes will be exempt for year seven. (4) Forty percent of post assessed rehabilitation property taxes will be exempt for year eight. (5) Twenty percent of post assessed rehabilitation property taxes will be exempt for year nine. (6) Zero percent abatement will begin at year ten. (Ord. No. 2013-024 , 10-21-13) Sec. 87-4. - Abatement of other fees. (a) The council may grant other incentives, as provided by O.C.G.A. § 36-88-7 and O.C.G.A. § 36-88-9. Such incentives will be negotiated by the mayor and council on a case-by-case basis and may include, but not limited to, exemptions from any or all of the following: occupation taxes, regulatory fees, building inspection fees, and other fees that would otherwise have been imposed on qualifying businesses or service enterprises. (b) The council may make determinations of eligibility for each qualifying business or service enterprise for abatement of additional fees based on the quality and quantity of such additional economic stimulus as may be created within the City of St. Marys. That qualifying business or service enterprises shall be defined a "business enterprise" meaning retail, manufacturing, warehousing and distribution, processing, telecommunications, tourism, research and development, new residential construction and rehabilitation. "Service enterprise" means finance, insurance, or real estate activities. Criteria for consideration may include, but not limited to the following: (1) The value of the business to the economic health and well-being of St. Marys and its citizens; (2) Capital investment or reinvestment by the business equal to or greater than the amount of ad valorem tax abated over the first five years of the tax incentive; (3) Locating in a vacant or historic building; (4) Demolishing an obsolete, abandoned and/or deteriorating pre-existing structure; (5) Enhancing the area by incorporating elements such as significant landscaping, area-compatible facade materials and exclusion of billboards on premises; (6) Assembling multiple tracts of land for one project; (7) Creating jobs above the state threshold; and (8) Creating jobs for residents of the enterprise zone and surrounding area. (Ord. No. 2013-024 , 10-21-13) Sec. 87-5. - Economic development director. The council further directs and designates the economic development director for the City of St. Marys to be appointed by the city manager to serve as liaison for communications with the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, the Georgia Department of Economic Development; the business community; and all others to oversee enterprise zone activities and administration, and communication with qualified business and qualified service enterprises as outlined in this chapter. (Ord. No. 2013-024 , 10-21-13) Sec. 87-6. - Contracts for compliance. The council has the power to administer, require, and enforce compliance with the provisions of the ordinance and such administrative rules or regulations adopted hereinafter by way of contract, resolution including, but not limited, to reports and data information from businesses within the enterprise zone to verify compliance with this chapter and state, and other means. Any qualifying business shall enter into a contractual agreement that outlines the incentives offered to the business and a guideline for the recapture, revocation, or reimbursement. Should the terms of the contract be violated by the target qualifying business or service enterprise the council may withdraw the qualifying enterprise designation of the business which will automatically reimpose any fees or subsequent taxes which had been abated. (Ord. No. 2013-024 , 10-21-13) Sec. 87-7. - Qualifying enterprises. All development in the enterprise zone which is deemed eligible for tax incentives must be initiated and developed by "qualifying business" or "qualifying service" enterprises (each of which are sometimes called "qualifying enterprises") which meet the criteria established herein (O.C.G.A. § 36-88-4). Criteria established for the enterprise zone includes that the qualifying business provides "economic stimulus" meeting the following criteria: (1) Creation of five full-time jobs; (2) When possible, ten percent of new employees shall be low-and moderate income individuals; or (3) Exemptions apply to any entity within the zone, for either residential and/or rehab of an existing structure where value of improvements is greater than 500 percent of land value. (Ord. No. 2013-024 , 10-21-13) Sec. 87-8. - Relationship to state law. In the event of a conflict between the provision of this and the "Enterprise Employment Zone Act of 1997" (the "Act"), the provision of the Act shall be controlling. (Ord. No. 2013-024 , 10-21-13)

div.head: Chapter 90 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Ad valorem tax, § 5-101; sanitary tax, § 5-102; occupation and business taxes, § 5-103; excise tax on alcoholic beverages, § 5-105; insurance premiums taxes and licenses, § 5-106; service charges for water, sewer, sanitary and health services, § 5-107; special assessment for street and sidewalk construction, § 5-108; other taxes, § 5-109. Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 10; businesses, ch. 22. Related laws reference— Homestead exemption, art. II; stabilized tax program, art. III. State Law reference— Taxation power of municipal governments, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 4, par. 1; limitation on taxing power of municipalities, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 8; ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-2; municipal taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq.; specific business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 90-1—90-35. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - AD VALOREM TAXES
Sec. 90-36. - Opening, closing of books for collection. (a) The day of opening the books, each year, for the collection of city taxes shall be the date of billing. (b) The books for the collection of city taxes without penalty shall close on December 31 or 60 days from the date of billing, whichever is the later date. (Ord. of 10-14-91, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 10-12-92, §§ 1, 2) Sec. 90-37. - Issuance of delinquent notice. The finance director and tax collector shall issue a delinquent notice to the owner of each piece of property on which taxes have not been paid at the time fixed for the closing of the tax books. (Ord. of 10-14-91, § 3; Ord. of 10-12-92, § 3; Ord. of 8-1-16 ) Sec. 90-38. - Issuance of fi fa notice. The finance director and tax collector shall issue a fi fa against the owner of each piece of property along with a notice of such on which taxes have not been paid by the 60 th day from the date of closing. (Ord. of 10-14-91, § 4; Ord. of 10-12-92, § 4; Ord. of 8-1-16 ) Sec. 90-39. - Expenses of advertising, other legal expenses added to tax. The expense of advertising and other legal expenses connected with the collection of taxes, on any property, shall be added to, and collected with, the taxes on the property. (Ord. of 10-14-91, § 5; Ord. of 10-12-92, § 5) Sec. 90-40. - Penalty and interest. From the date of issue of each tax bill the following fees shall be applied, when applicable, beginning on the 61st day from the date of billing: (1) Interest at the rate of 12 percent (annual rate) or one percent per month to be computed on the day the tax bill is paid from the closing date. (2) Penalty for each delinquent notice at the rate of $10.00 or ten percent, whichever is greater. (3) Fi fa fee on each fi fa issued at the rate of $15.00. (Ord. of 10-14-91, § 6; Ord. of 10-12-92, § 6) Sec. 90-41. - No special privileges; sale of property upon exhaustion of other means of collection; amount of tax sale. There will be no special privileges given to any taxpayer in paying his tax bills and any legal means in which to collect the taxes will be used and if all other means have been exhausted in collecting the taxes, a property sale will be conducted with proper notice given to each owner of the property. No sale for taxes shall be held unless the aggregate amount of taxes owed on a property exceeds $10.00. (Ord. of 10-14-91, § 7; Ord. of 8-15-16 ) Sec. 90-42. - Issuance of executions. All executions in favor of the city for the enforcement and collection of any fine, forfeiture, assessment or tax shall be issued by the city clerk or finance director and shall be directed to the chief of police or any of his deputies, and shall state for what issued. Such executions shall state the purpose for which they are issued and shall be made returnable to the mayor and council 90 days after their issuance. (Ord. of 12-3-81, § 1; Ord. of 8-1-16 ) Sec. 90-43. - Advertisement of sale of property; conduct of sale. It shall be the duty of the finance director or collecting officer to advertise the sale of such real estate or personal property as may have been levied upon by him to satisfy the execution in the same manner respectively as sheriffs' sales of real property or constables' sales of personal property are required by law to be made. All of the sales shall be made at the place and within the usual hours of sale that sheriffs' and constables' sales are made, and under the same rules and regulations governing sheriffs' sales and constables' sales of similar property. The time, place and manner of sale of property, both real and personal, for taxes due, shall be the same as provided by law for sales under execution for state and county taxes. Whenever any land is sold for taxes, the owner thereof shall have the privilege of redeeming it within one year by paying the purchaser the amount thereof, with ten percent premium thereon. (Ord. of 12-3-81, § 2; Ord. of 8-1-16 ) Sec. 90-44. - Acquisition of property by city. Whenever at such sales no one present shall bid for the property put up for sale as much as the amount of such execution and all costs, and after such property shall have been cried for a reasonable time, then any duly appointed or authorized agent of the city, the city attorney, the city clerk, the mayor or any councilmember, may bid off such property for the city, and the chief of police or such other officer making the sale shall make the city a deed to the property so sold and deliver it, and the title thus acquired by the city shall be perfect and valid after the period provided for redemption by the owner has expired and all other requirements of the law shall have been met. The chief of police or other officer making the sale shall put the city in possession of the property. (Ord. of 12-3-81, § 3) Sec. 90-45. - Execution docket; return to clerk's office upon satisfaction. The city clerk shall enter on an execution docket all executions, giving the date, amount of each, and to whom delivered, and all proceedings thereunder. The execution shall be returned to the office of the city clerk after being satisfied. All sales and conveyances made under execution as provided in this article shall have all of the force and effect of sales and conveyances made by sheriffs of this state, and the officer making the sale shall have the same power as the sheriff to put purchasers in possession of property sold by them. (Ord. of 12-3-81, § 4) Sec. 90-46. - Costs, fees associated with sale. For levy, advertising, sales and other duties of like kind in the sale of property for the city taxes, fines, forfeitures, and assessments, the finance director shall be allowed the same costs and fees as are now allowed the sheriffs in this state for performing similar duties, together with all other costs incurred by the city in preparing for and conducting the sale. (Ord. of 12-3-81, § 5; Ord. of 8-1-16 ) Sec. 90-47. - Due date for payment. The due date for payment of all ad valorem property taxes for the city shall be 60 days from the date of mailing of tax bills by the city. (Ord. of 12-3-81, § 6) Sec. 90-48. - Remedies, rights allowed for collection and payment. Any remedy or right allowed by law for the enforcement of the collection and payment of state property taxes, either by the commissioner, tax commissioner or tax collector, may be used for the enforcement of the collection and payment of municipal property taxes by the city. (Ord. of 7-3-84) Sec. 90-49. - Tax lien enforcement provisions. (a) Adoption of O.C.G.A., title 48, article 5 by reference. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-4-76(a), O.C.G.A. §§ 48-44-77 through 48-4-81 are hereby adopted by reference as an alternative and supplemental method and remedy for the enforcement of ad valorem tax liens by the city. (b) Supplemental effect. It is the intention of the mayor and council in the passage and enactment of this section that its provisions shall be supplemental and alternative to existing city ordinances relating to delinquent tax collections and that this section shall not be interpreted or construed so as to expressly or implied repeal other existing city ordinances dealing with the same subject matter embraced herein. (Ord. of 10-23-95, §§ 1, 2) Editor's note— An ordinance adopted March 10, 1997(1), provided for the inclusion of the provisions of an ordinance adopted Oct. 23, 1995, as § 90-49 of the Code. Secs. 90-50—90-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - EXCISE TAX ON LODGINGS AND ACCOMMODATIONS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— County and municipal excise taxes on rooms, lodgings and accommodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq.; operators of hotels, inns and roadhouses, O.C.G.A. § 43-21-1 et seq.
Sec. 90-71. - Levy. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51 et seq., there is hereby levied and imposed an excise tax of six percent upon the furnishing for value to the public of any room or rooms, lodging, or accommodations furnished by any person or legal entity licensed by, or required to pay business or occupation taxes to the city for operating a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings, or accommodations are regularly furnished for value. (Ord. of 9-22-86; Ord. of 4-13-92; Ord. of 6-13-05, § 1) Sec. 90-72. - Payment of tax. (a) Filing of report. Each business or establishment subject to the levy and collection of the hotel-motel tax shall, on or before the 20th day of each month, prepare and file with the city finance director a hotel-motel occupancy tax report on all taxes due for the preceding month. Such report shall be in the form as prescribed by the city finance director. If the 20th day of the month falls upon a weekend or upon a city or national holiday the report shall be filed on the next business day following such weekend or city or national holiday. (b) Due date. The excise tax due to the city shall be paid at the time of the filing of the report. (c) Credit. Each business or establishment subject to the levy and collection of the tax shall be entitled to a credit against such tax as a vendor's collection fee of three percent of the total tax provided the return and tax due is not delinquent. (Ord. of 5-9-94(1), § (A)) Sec. 90-73. - Delinquent payment; penalty for failure to make report or pay full amount. (a) The tax imposed by this article shall become delinquent for each month after the 20th day of each succeeding month during which it remains unpaid. The city clerk may, when any tax becomes delinquent under this article, issue a fi fa or tax execution for the collection of such tax, interest, and penalty from each delinquent taxpayer or establishment subject to the tax. (b) When any establishment or taxpayer fails to make any report or to pay the full amount of the tax required by this article, there shall be imposed the following penalties and interest: (1) A penalty to be added to the tax in the amount of five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, if the report and payment of tax is delinquent with an additional five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, for each additional month or fraction thereof, following the 20th of the month during which the delinquency continues. (2) Interest upon all delinquent taxes imposed by this article shall be due the city as the rate of one percent of the unpaid tax and penalties per month from the date delinquent until paid to the city. (Ord. of 9-22-86, § 2; Ord. of 5-9-94(1), § (B)) Sec. 90-74. - Exemptions. The tax levied by this article shall not apply to those charges for the furnishings for value to the public of any room or rooms, lodgings, or accommodations which are exempt from taxation under applicable state law. (Ord. of 9-22-86, §§ 3, 4; Ord. No. 2015-016 , 5-18-15) Sec. 90-75. - Use of proceeds. The proceeds of this tax shall be used in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)4(f). (Ord. of 6-13-05, § 2) Editor's note— Section 2 of an ordinance adopted June 13, 2005, deleted former § 90-75 of the Code in its entirety and added new provisions to the Code as § 90-75. Former § 90-75 of the Code pertained to the tax rate and derived from ordinances adopted Sept. 22, 1986, and April 13, 1992. Secs. 90-76—90-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS BUSINESS LICENSE TAX
Sec. 90-101. - Levy. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93 there is hereby levied an annual business license tax upon state and national banking associations, federal savings and loan associations, state building and loan associations a business license tax at the rate of .25 percent of the gross receipts of the institutions as defined. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, the minimum amount of business license tax due from any depository financial institutions pursuant to this article shall be $1,000.00 per year. (Ord. of 12-20-83, § 1) Sec. 90-102. - Calculation of gross receipts. For purposes of this article "gross receipts" shall mean the total amount of revenue generated from the sources itemized below during the calendar year immediately preceding the date on which the tax imposed by this article is due: (1) Items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts with respect to banks are as follows: a. Interest and fees on loans, less any interest collected on those portions of loans sold and serviced for others. b. Interest on balances with other depository financial institutions. c. Interest on federal or correspondent funds sold and securities purchased under agreements of resale. d. Interest on other bonds, notes, and debentures, excluding interest on obligations in the state or its political subdivisions and obligations on the United States. e. Dividends on stocks. f. Income from direct lease financing. g. Income from fiduciary activities. h. Service charges on deposit accounts. i. Other service charges, commissions, and fees. j. Other income. (2) Items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts with respect to savings and loan associations are as follows: a. Interest on mortgage loans less any interest collected on those portions of loans sold in service for others. b. Interest on mortgages, participations, or mortgage-backed securities. c. Interest on real estate sold on contract. d. Discounts on mortgage loans purchased. e. Interest on other loans, excluding interest on obligations of the state or its political subdivisions and obligations of the United States. f. Interest and dividends on investments and deposits. g. Loan fees. h. Loan servicing fees. i. Other fees and charges. j. Gross income from real estate owned operations. k. Gross income from office building operations. l. Gross income from real estate held for investment. m. Net income from service corporations and subsidiaries. n. Miscellaneous operating income. o. Profit on sale of real estate owned, investment securities, loans, and other assets. p. Miscellaneous nonoperating income. (3) The following items shall be deducted from gross receipts calculated pursuant to subsection (1) or (2) of this section: a. An amount equal to the amount of interest paid on all liabilities for the period. b. An amount equal to income derived from the authorized activities of any domestic international banking facility operating pursuant to O.C.G.A. tit. 7, ch. 1, art. 5(a). c. An amount equal to any income arising from the conduct of a banking business with persons or entities located outside of the United States, its territories or possessions. d. An amount equal to a depository financial institution's gross income which is taxed under the tax laws of a state other than Georgia. e. To the extent that any deductions are made pursuant to subsections (3)b, c and d of this section, any deductions taken under subsection (3)a of this section shall be reduced by the same proportion that the deductions in subsections (3)b through d of this section bear to the gross receipts of the depository financial institution as calculated before making any deductions pursuant to subsections (3)a through d above. (Ord. of 12-20-83, § 2) Sec. 90-103. - Due date; filing of return. Each depository financial institution within the city shall file a return of its gross receipts with the city on March 1 of the year following the year in which such gross receipts were measured. The returns shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of banking and shall be based upon the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The tax levied pursuant to this article shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in the return. (Ord. of 12-20-83, § 3) Secs. 90-104—90-130. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - INSURERS' LICENSE FEES AND TAXES[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— County and municipal corporation tax on life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1; county and municipal corporation tax on other than life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2.
Sec. 90-131. - Insurer license fees. There is hereby levied for the year 2002 and for each year thereafter an annual license fee upon each insurer doing business within the city in the amount of $75.00. For each separate business location in excess of one not covered by section 90-132, which is operating on behalf of such insurers within the city, there is hereby levied a license fee in the amount of $75.00. For the purposes of this article, the term "insurer" means a company, which is authorized to transact business in any of the classes of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5. (Ord. of 10-4-83(1); Ord. of 7-13-92, § 1; Ord. of 11-12-01, § 1) Sec. 90-132. - License fee for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations. For each separate business location, not otherwise subject to a license fee hereunder, operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing and in connection with such loans or sales offers, solicits or takes application for insurance through a licensed agent of an insurer for insurance said insurer shall pay an additional license fee of $26.25 per location for the year 2002 and for each year thereafter. (Ord. of 10-4-83(1); Ord. of 7-13-92, § 2; Ord. of 11-12-01, § 2) Sec. 90-133. - Insurance agency license fees; independent insurance agencies, brokers, etc., not otherwise licensed. There is hereby levied an annual license fee upon independent agencies and brokers for each separate business location from which an insurance business is conducted and which is not subject to the company license fee imposed by section 90-131, in the amount of $40.00 for each such location within the city. (Ord. of 10-4-83(1); Ord. of 7-13-92, § 3) Sec. 90-134. - Gross premiums tax imposed on life insurers. There is hereby levied for the year 2002 and for each thereafter an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance within the state in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. Gross direct premiums as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 90-131. (Ord. of 10-4-83(1); Ord. of 7-13-92, § 4; Ord. of 11-12-01, § 3) Sec. 90-135. - Gross premiums tax, all other insurers. There is hereby levied for the year 2002 and for each year thereafter an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in subsection 1 of O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5, doing business within the State of Georgia in an amount equal to 2.5 percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. Gross direct premiums as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 90-131. (Ord. of 10-4-83(1); Ord. of 7-13-92, § 5; Ord. of 11-12-01, § 4) Sec. 90-136. - Due date for license fees. License fees imposed in sections 90-131 and 90-132 shall be due and payable on the first day of 2002 and on the first date of each subsequent year. (Ord. of 10-4-83(1); Ord. of 7-13-92, § 6; Ord. of 11-12-01, § 5) Secs. 90-137—90-155. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - OCCUPATIONAL LICENSE TAX ON TELEPHONE COMPANIES
Sec. 90-156. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Recurring local service revenues means: (1) Monthly charges for local exchange service, including: a. Charges for additional listings and joint users. b. The guarantee portion of the charge for semipublic pay station services. c. Charges for local message rate service, including mobile service local messages. d. Subscriber station revenues from teletypewriter exchange service. (2) Charges for Morse transmission, signaling, data transmission, remote metering and supervisory control, where both terminal points are within the city limits. (3) All charges for local private line services (except audio and video program transmission services) where both terminals of the private line are within the city limits. (4) Nothing in the definition shall preclude the charging of a separate franchise fee for the transmission of audio or video programs to customers by CATV companies. (Ord. of 4-5-79(2), § 2) Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. Sec. 90-157. - Levy. Each telephone company operating in the city shall pay an occupational license tax in the amount of three percent of the recurring local service revenues received by such company from subscribers located within the city. The occupational license tax shall be paid in quarterly installments, each of which shall be due on or before the last day of the second month following the end of each calendar quarter and shall be based on recurring local service revenues billed during such calendar quarter. The first payment under this article shall be based on revenues billed between the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives and the end of the calendar quarter in which such effective date falls. Any amount of license tax previously paid and absorbed by a telephone company which is applicable to any period subsequent to the effective date of this article shall be credited against the amounts imposed herein or by subsequent ordinance. (Ord. of 4-5-79(2), § 1) Secs. 90-158—90-170. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - SENIOR CITIZEN'S HOMESTEAD EXEMPTION
Sec. 90-171. - Homestead ad valorem taxation exemption. Those persons 65 years of age or older and who otherwise meet the qualifications and criterion specified in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-47(b) shall be entitled to a senior citizen's homestead ad valorem taxation exemption upon the terms and conditions as set forth in the afore-cited section of the Official Code of Georgia. (Ord. of 3-10-97(2), § 1) Secs. 90-172—90-180. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - DISABLED VETERAN'S HOMESTEAD AND VEHICLE AD VALOREM TAXATION EXEMPTIONS
Sec. 90-181. - Homestead exemption from municipal ad valorem taxation. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-48, any disabled veteran meeting the definition, qualifications and criterion set forth therein shall be entitled to the homestead exemption from municipal ad valorem taxation upon the terms, conditions, and requirements set forth in such section of the Official Code of Georgia. (Ord. of 3-10-97(2), § 2) Sec. 90-182. - Vehicle ad valorem taxation exemption. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-478, any disabled veteran who meets the qualifications and criterion set forth therein shall be entitled to exemption from all ad valorem taxation upon the vehicle he owns and on which he actually places the free HV motor vehicle license tag he receives from the State of Georgia. (Ord. of 3-10-97(2), § 2)

div.head: Chapter 94 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Open containers, § 10-46 et seq.; courts, ch. 38; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 70; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82; vehicles for hire, ch. 106. State Law reference— Authority to provide devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const., art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(a)(4); Uniform Rules of the Road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; power of local authorities generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371; adoption of uniform rules of the road by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372; prosecution of traffic offenses, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 94-1. - Uniform rules of the road adopted. (a) Adoption by reference. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. ch. 6, title 40, §§ 40-6-372 through 40-6-376, and §§ 40-6-1 through 40-6-395, known as the Uniform Rules of the Road and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this municipality with like effect as if fully recited herein. (b) Penalties. Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 or by imprisonment for not more than 90 days or by both such fine and imprisonment. (Ord. of 9-25-95, §§ 1, 2) Editor's note— Section 3 of an ordinance adopted Sept. 25, 1995, repealed an ordinance adopted Oct. 4, 1983, § II of which had been included within the Code as § 94-1. Sections 1 and 2 of the ordinance adopted Sept. 25, 1995, enacted similar new provisions which have been included herein as § 94-1. Sec. 94-2. - No parking areas. It shall be illegal to park within the city in all areas that are marked "no parking". (Ord. of 9-4-84) Sec. 94-3. - Two-hour parking. (a) It shall be unlawful in the following designated areas to permit, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., any vehicle to remain parked in an on-street parking space for a consecutive period of more than two hours. (b) This prohibition shall apply to the following locations: (1) Osborne Street from the intersection of Bryant Street south to St. Marys Street. (2) St. Marys Street from the intersection of the east right-of-way of Osborne Street to the intersection of Wheeler Street. (c) For the purposes of this section, the term "vehicle" shall mean any vehicle or wheeled conveyance including, but not limited to, automobiles, trucks, trailers, motorcycles and bicycles. (d) Violation of this section shall be punishable by: (1) The towing-away and impoundment of the violating vehicle, with the cost of such towing and impoundment to be paid by the violator; and/or (2) A fine of $25.00. (Ord. of 5-11-92) Sec. 94-4. - Stopping, standing or parking. (a) The stopping, standing or parking of vehicles is prohibited within the limits of the area described as follows: That segment of roadway on both sides of State Route 40 Spur beginning 75 feet south of the south driveway at the Crooked River Elementary School, mile post 3.44, then north for a distance of 900 feet, mile post 3.61. (b) Signs are to be erected by the department of transportation maintenance forces. (c) Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished as provided for in section 1-12. This section shall become effective when appropriate signs are erected. (Ord. of 1-11-93; Ord. of 4-26-93) Sec. 94-5. - Speed zones. (a) Pursuant to an engineering and traffic investigation as prescribed by law, the following are determined and declared to be reasonable and safe maximum vehicle speed limits within the zones or areas described, to wit: ON-SYSTEM ROADWAYS
OFF-SYSTEM ROADWAYS
Note— * School Zones are effective: a.m. from 45 minutes prior to commencement time to 15 minutes after commencement time. School days only. p.m. from 30 minutes prior to dismissal time to 30 minutes after dismissal time. School days only. (b) Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 or by imprisonment for not more than 90 days or by both such fine and imprisonment. (Ord. of 6-10-96, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 9-11-97; Ord. of 9-18-00; Ord. of 5-23-05; Ord. of 7-11-07; Ord. of 7-13-09) Sec. 94-6. - Colerain Road load limit prohibition. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate a bimodal semitrailer, combination of vehicles, trailer, semitrailer, truck tractor or any other motor vehicle having a gross weight in excess of 15,000 pounds or more upon that city street or roadway known as "Colerain Road" between the intersection of Colerain Road and Georgia Spur 40 and the intersection of Colerain Road and the Kings Bay Road cut, in either direction. (b) This section, however, shall not prohibit the operation of any vehicle to a destination upon such section of Colerain Road or any side street or roadway connected thereto, nor shall it prohibit the operation thereon of emergency vehicles, vehicles owned and operated by the city, any public utility, the county board of education, or the county board of commissioners. (c) For the purposes of the construction, application and prosecution of this section, the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. §§ 40-1-1 and 32-6-24(a)(1) are hereby adopted and incorporated herein by reference as if the same were fully set forth herein. (d) Warning and enforcement signs shall be posted on Colerain Road at its intersections with Kings Bay Road, St. Marys Road and Georgia Spur 40 at intervals not to exceed one-quarter mile. Such signs shall meet the specifications and requirements contained in the U.S. Department of Transportation's Uniform Code of Traffic Devices (as revised). (e) Any person in violation of this section of the Code of Ordinances shall be conclusively presumed to have damaged the said section of Colerain Road. (f) Any person in violation of the provisions hereof shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, or by imprisonment not to exceed six months, or both. (Ord. of 10-26-98, § 1) Sec. 94-7. - Waterfront—St. Marys Street parking restrictions. (a) No person who owns or has possession, control or custody of any vehicle shall park that vehicle for more than 36 continuous hours in the parking spaces designated and maintained on the south side of St. Marys Street from the point of intersection of the southernmost right-of-way of said street with the westernmost right-of-way of Margaret Street (as extended), to the intersection of the said southernmost right-of-way of said St. Marys Street and the easternmost right-of-way of Osborne Street (as extended). (b) The changing of the position of a vehicle from one point directly to another point within the above-described area shall be deemed one continuous parking period. (c) Any person or persons cited for a violation of this section shall be deemed to be charged with a noncriminal infraction and shall be cited to appear before the municipal court of the city. Violations of this section shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $100.00. (d) Whenever any vehicle is found parked in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by this section, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user and shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a notice in writing, on a form approved by the chief of police, for the driver to answer to the charge against him/her at the time and place specified in the notice. (e) At any hearing of the case involving illegal parking in which the owner of the vehicle is being tried under this section, it shall be sufficient evidence on which the court may rely to establish the name of the registered owner of such vehicle if a police officer, or a designee of the city shall state on oath that he/she has made inquiry of the Georgia or any state's department of motor vehicles and has been advised by such department of the identity of the registered owner. However, if the person on trial denies that he/she is the registered owner, and such fact cannot be otherwise established, the court may defer the final determination of the case until a certified record or appropriate certificate can be obtained from the office of the appropriate department of motor vehicles showing the record in that office on the date in question. (f) At any hearing of a case involving illegal parking in which the owner of the motor vehicle is being tried under this section, the judge may, in his/her discretion, allow any person, whether the registered owner or not, to testify or otherwise give evidence if the person admits under oath or affirmation to have parked the vehicle at the time and place of the alleged offense. (g) Temporary parking for loading and unloading vehicles has been designated for use by persons using the Cumberland Island ferry from the Osprey II dock off Ready Street. The parking spaces affected by this temporary ordinance provision include all parking spaces on the southbound side of Ready Street, between Stable Alley and St. Marys Street, and designated parking spaces on the east end St. Marys Street. The provisions for the uses of these parking spaces are as follow: (1) Parking is only authorized for a duration not to exceed 15 minutes. (2) Enforcement of this parking requirement will be from 8:00 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. daily. (3) Vehicles that are found to be in violation of this requirement are subject to being towed at the owner's expense by the St. Marys Police Department. (4) Over-night parking in the designated parking spaces is forbidden at all times. (5) Subsection (g) and all of its contents will remain in effect until November 6, 2019 unless otherwise determined by the St. Marys City Council. (6) All affected parking spaces will be plainly designated by proper signage. (Ord. of 8-9-99, § 1; Ord. No. 2017-11-6-003 , 11-6-17) Sec. 94-8. - Establishment of four-way stop intersections and three-way stop intersections. (a) The following city street intersections shall be four-way stop intersections, to wit: (1) Intersection of South Julia Street and Borrell Boulevard; (2) Intersection of Gunter Street, Bowen Street and Durden Street; (3) Intersection of Plantation Drive and Cherry Point Drive; (4) Intersection of McIntosh Drive and McQueen Circle; (5) Intersection of Shadowlawn Drive and Longwood Road; (6) Intersection of Miller Street and Borrell Boulevard; (7) Intersection of Finley Street and Seagrove Street; and (8) Intersection of Silver Fox Drive and Avondale Drive. (b) The following city street intersection shall be a three-way stop intersection, to wit: (1) Intersection of McIntosh Drive and Bachlott Road. (c) Additional four-way or three-way stop intersections shall be established and designated by way of an ordinance duly enacted by the mayor and city council. (Ord. of 8-13-01, § 1) Sec. 94-8.1. - Water-borne vessel registration and use of waterfront docks. (a) All water-borne vessels over 12 feet in length shall either be registered with the Georgia Department of Natural Resources (DNR), License and Boat Registration Unit, Wildlife Resources Division; or carry valid registration from another state or country; or carry valid proof of ownership (except for canoes, kayaks, prams, etc. that do not have a mechanical form of propulsion, or sailing vessels which are less than 12 feet in length). This data must be visible and/or accessible and available for inspection when requested by any law enforcement officer of Georgia. (b) All water-borne vessel operators are required to obey laws that regulate the water-borne vessels registration, operation and comply with water-borne vessel education. (c) The registration number and validation decal must be displayed in a manner as defined in the Georgia DNR rules. Owners of water-borne vessels not displaying the required numbers, or where the numbers displayed are not listed on the current listing of valid Georgia registrations, may be cited for non-registration as well as for docking not in compliance with this section. (d) No person who owns or has possession, control or custody of any water-borne vessel shall tie up to the docks as designated below for more than the time noted below and/or on the dock. (1) DNR-owned wooden kayak dock - no more than 30 minutes per four-hour period. No overnight docking. (2) City-owned concrete "fireworks" dock connected to the DNR kayak dock - no more than six hours in a 12-hour period. No overnight docking. (3) City-owned wood/concrete Wheeler Street ramp and dock - no more than 30 minutes per four-hour period. No overnight docking. (4) City-owned concrete pavilion fishing dock - no water-borne vessel tie up for any reason. (5) City-owned wood Gateway dock - no more than eight hours per 12-hour period. No overnight docking. (6) DNR-owned concrete Miller Street dock and ramp - no more than 30 minutes per four-hour period. No overnight docking. (7) DNR wooden fishing dock at Gilman Park - no water-borne vessel tie up for any reason. (8) City-owned wooden Marsh Walk - no water-borne vessel tie up for any reason. (e) The moving of a water-borne vessel from one mooring point on a dock to another mooring point on the same dock will make up one continuous docking period. (f) Any owner of any water-borne vessel overstaying the limits as noted above and as noted on the dock and/or ramp, will - upon notification by the appropriate designated official of the City of St. Marys - immediately relocate the water-borne vessel as required to comply with this section. If so moved, the water-borne vessel and its owners shall not be charged with a violation. (g) If the owner of a water-borne vessel fails to comply with the requirements to move the water-borne vessel that is in violation of this section, the owner or occupant of the water-borne vessel may be cited for a violation of this section. Violations of this section shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $300.00 per occurrence. (Ord. No. 2013-019 , 6-17-13) ARTICLE II. - REGULATION OF LOW SPEED MOTOR VEHICLES
Sec. 94-9. - Short title. This [article] shall be known as the "St. Marys Low Speed Motor Vehicle Ordinance". (Ord. of 3-22-04, § 1) Sec. 94-10. - Definition. Low-speed motor vehicle (LSMV): means any four-wheeled electric vehicle or gas-powered vehicle, whose top speed attainable in one mile is greater than 20 miles per hour, but not greater than 25 miles per hour on a paved level surface, and which is manufactured in compliance with those federal motor vehicle safety standards for low-speed vehicles set forth in 49 C.F.R. Section 571.500 and in effect on January 1, 2001. Motorized cart: means every motor vehicle having no less than three wheels and an unladen weight of 1,300 pounds or less, and which cannot operate at more than 20 miles per hour. (Ord. of 3-22-04, § 1; Ord. of 4-14-08(2), § 1) Sec. 94-11. - Operation regulations. (a) Those persons who are 16 years of age and older possessing a current state license to operate a motor vehicle, may drive a LSMV or motorized cart on the streets and those areas accessible by the public of the City of St. Marys, unless such person has had his or her license to operate a motor vehicle suspended or revoked by the state which issued said license, in which case such person shall not be permitted to operate a LSMV or motorized cart on the LSMV or motorized cart streets and those areas accessible by the public of the city during the time of suspension or revocation. (b) Those persons who are 15 years of age but not yet 16 years of age, may drive a LSMV or motorized cart on the streets and those areas accessible by the public of the city provided he or she has in his or her possession a valid instructional permit issued by the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-5-24, as may be amended, and has not had his or her instructional permit suspended or revoked, and he or she shall be accompanied in the front seat by a person at least 18 years of age who holds a valid motor vehicle driver's license. (Ord. of 3-22-04, § 1; Ord. of 4-14-08(2), § 2) Sec. 94-12. - LSMV registration. (a) Before any LSMV may be used or operated within the corporate limits of the City of St. Marys, as a public conveyance for hire, or as a rental vehicle, it shall be registered with the St. Marys Police Department and receive a decal from that department signifying its regulation. (b) There shall be a fee of $100.00 for registration and such decal shall be attached and displayed on all registered LSMV's so as to be plainly visible. (c) Registration shall be accomplished by means of an LSMV registration application in a form prescribed by the Chief of the St. Marys Police Department and shall be accompanied, when filed, with evidence of public liability insurance coverage in the following specified limits for such occurrence:
(d) All operators of LSMV's shall abide by all traffic regulations applicable to vehicular traffic when using the streets and those areas accessible by the public in the city. (e) LSMV's shall not be operated on sidewalks at any time. (f) LSMV's may be operated over those streets, and those areas accessible by the public only during daylight hours unless such motorized carts are equipped with functional headlights and taillights. (g) Every person operating a LSMV shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to all the rules of the road and duties applicable to the driver of any other vehicle under this chapter except as to special regulations in this part and except as to those provisions of this chapter which by their nature can have no application. (h) All LSMV's are entitled to full use of a lane, and no motor vehicle shall be driven in such a manner as to deprive any low-speed vehicle of the full use of a lane. (j) The operator of an LSMV shall not overtake and pass in the same lane occupied by the vehicle being overtaken. (k) No person shall operate an LSMV between lanes of traffic or between adjacent lines or rows of vehicles. (l) LSMV's shall not be operated two or more abreast in a single lane. (m) LSMV's shall be operated only on any street where the posted speed limit does not exceed 35 miles per hour. The operator of a LSMV shall not operate such vehicle on any street where the posted speed limit exceeds 35 miles per hour except to cross this street at or near a 90-degree angle. (n) No individual or group operating or driving LSMV's shall engage in hazardous activities on the streets and those areas accessible by the public. Such hazardous activities, and the special rules pertaining to them, include but are not limited to the following: (1) Racing of any form, except for special events approved by the city; and (2) Blocking of public access, except for special events approved by the city. (o) All laws and ordinances relative to alcohol and its use, including open container laws, which apply to traffic on the streets of the city also apply to operators of LSMV's. (p) All operators and passengers must remain seated at all times during the operation of the LSMV. No person may sit on the operator's lap during the operation of the LSMV. (q) During civic activities, festivals and parades, LSMV's shall not be permitted unless specially authorized to do so, to operate within areas where motor vehicle operation is restricted or prohibited. (r) Before any LSMV may be operated upon city streets or public areas of the city, it shall have installed thereon: (1) An emblem as required by O.C.G.A. § 40-8-4. The emblem shall conform to those standards and specifications adopted by slow-moving vehicles by the American Society of Agricultural Engineers in December 1966, and contained within such society's standard ASAE S276.1, or shall be an emblem of the same shape and size painted on such vehicle in a bright and conspicuous retro-reflective red-orange paint. Such emblem shall be mounted on the rear of such vehicles, in the approximate horizontal geometric center of the vehicle, at the height of three feet to five feet above the roadway, and shall be maintained at all times in a clean and reflective condition. (2) An amber strobe light as required by O.C.G.A. § 40-8-35. (s) Each person operating an LSMV is liable for his or her own actions. Liability insurance coverage varies and each person operating an LSMV on city streets or within public areas shall maintain liability insurance coverage and each person operating an LSMV shall, upon request by law enforcement personnel, very such coverage. (Ord. of 3-22-04, § 1; Ord. of 3-22-04, § 1; Ord. of 4-14-08(2), § 2) Sec. 94-13. - LSMV "not for hire" regulations. (a) All operators of LSMVs shall abide by all traffic regulations applicable to vehicular traffic when using the streets and those areas accessible by the public in the city. (b) LSMVs shall not be operated on sidewalks at any time. (c) LSMVs may be operated over those streets, and those areas accessible by the public only during daylight hours unless such LSMVs are equipped with functional headlights and taillights. (d) Every person operating a LSMVs shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to all the rules of the road and duties applicable to the driver of any other vehicle under this chapter except as to special regulations in this part and except as to those provisions of this chapter which by their nature can have no application. (e) All LSMVs are entitled to full use of a lane, and no motor vehicle shall be driven in such a manner as to deprive any LSMV of the full use of a lane. (f) The operator of a LSMV shall not overtake and pass in the same lane occupied by the vehicle being overtaken. (g) No person shall operate a LSMV between lanes of traffic or between adjacent lines or rows of vehicles. (h) LSMV shall not be operated two or more abreast in a single lane. (i) LSMVs shall be operated only on any street where the posted speed limit does not exceed 35 miles per hour. The operator of a LSMV shall not operate such vehicle on any street where the posted speed limit exceeds 35 miles per hour except to cross this street at or near a 90 degree angle. (j) No individual or group operating or driving LSMVs shall engage in hazardous activities on the streets and those areas accessible by the public. Such hazardous activities, and the special rules pertaining to them, include but are not limited to the following: (1) Racing of any form, except for special events approved by the city; and (2) Blocking of public access, except for special events approved by the city. (k) All laws and ordinances relative to alcohol and its use, including open container laws, which apply to traffic on the streets of the city also apply to operators of LSMVs. (l) All operators and passengers must remain seated at all times during the operation of the LSMV. No person may sit on the operator's lap during the operation of the LSMV. (m) During civic activities, festivals and parades, LSMVs shall not be permitted unless specially authorized to do so, to operate within areas where motor vehicle operation is restricted or prohibited. (n) Before any LSMV may be operated upon city streets or public areas of the city, it shall have installed thereon: (1) An emblem as required by O.C.G.A. § 40-8-4. The emblem shall conform to those standards and specifications adopted by slow-moving vehicles by the American Society of Agricultural Engineers in December 1966, and contained within such society's standard ASAE S276.6, or shall be an emblem of the same shape and size painted on such vehicle in a bright and conspicuous retro-reflective, red-orange paint. Such emblem shall be mounted on the rear of such vehicles, in the approximate horizontal geometric center of the vehicle, at the height of three feet to five feet above the roadway, and shall be maintained at all times in a clean and reflective condition. (2) An amber strobe light as required by O.C.G.A. § 40-8-35. (o) Each person operating an LSMV is liable for his or her own actions. Liability insurance coverage varies and each person operating an LSMV on city streets or within public areas shall maintain liability insurance coverage and each person operating an LSMV shall, upon request by law enforcement personnel, verify such coverage. (Ord. of 4-14-08(2), § 3) Editor's note— Ord. of April 14, 2008(2), §§ 3, 5, renamed § 94-13 as set out herein. Former § 94-13 pertained to penalties. See § 94-15 for penalty provisions. Sec. 94-14. - Motorized cart regulations. (a) All operators of motorized carts shall abide by all traffic regulations applicable to vehicular traffic when using the streets and those areas accessible by the public in the city. (b) Motorized carts shall not be operated on sidewalks at any time. (c) Motorized carts may be operated over those streets, and those areas accessible by the public only during daylight hours unless such motorized carts are equipped with functional headlights and taillights. (d) Every person operating a motorized cart shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to all the rules of the road and duties applicable to the driver of any other vehicle under this chapter except as to special regulations in this part and except as to those provisions of this chapter which by their nature can have no application. (e) All motorized carts are entitled to full use of a lane, and no motor vehicle shall be driven in such a manner as to deprive any motorized cart of the full use of a lane. (f) The operator of a motorized cart shall not overtake and pass in the same lane occupied by the vehicle being overtaken. (g) No person shall operate a motorized cart between lanes of traffic or between adjacent lines or rows of vehicles. (h) Motorized carts shall not be operated two or more abreast in a single lane. (i) Motorized carts shall be operated only on any street where the posted speed limit does not exceed 35 miles per hour. The operator of a motorized cart shall not operate such vehicle on any street where the posted speed limit exceeds 35 miles per hour except to cross this street at or near a 90 degree angle. (j) No individual or group operating or driving motorized carts shall engage in hazardous activities on the streets and those areas accessible by the public. Such hazardous activities, and the special rules pertaining to them, include, but are not limited to the following: (1) Racing of any form, except for special events approved by the city; and (2) Blocking of public access, except for special events approved by the city. (k) All laws and ordinances relative to alcohol and its use, including open container laws, which apply to traffic on the streets of the city also apply to operators of motorized carts. (l) All operators and passengers must remain seated at all times during the operation of the motorized cart. No person may sit on the operator's lap during the operation of the motorized cart. (m) During civic activities, festivals and parades, motorized carts shall not be permitted unless specially authorized to do so, to operate within areas where motor vehicle operation is restricted or prohibited. (n) Before any motorized cart may be operated upon city streets or public areas of the city, it shall have installed thereon: (1) An emblem as required by O.C.G.A. § 40-8-4. The emblem shall conform to those standards and specifications adopted by slow-moving vehicles by the American Society of Agricultural Engineers in December 1966, and contained within such society's standard ASAE S276.6, or shall be an emblem of the same shape and size painted on such vehicle in a bright and conspicuous retro-reflective, red-orange paint. Such emblem shall be mounted on the rear of such vehicles, in the approximate horizontal geometric center of the vehicle, at the height of three feet to five feet above the roadway, and shall be maintained at all times in a clean and reflective condition. (2) An amber strobe light as required by O.C.G.A. § 40-8-35. (o) Each person operating a motorized cart is liable for his or her own actions. (Ord. of 4-14-08(2), § 4) Sec. 94-15. - Penalties. (a) Any person who violates the terms of this article, shall be punished as follows: (1) For the first offense, a fine of not less than $50.00. (2) For the second offense, a fine of not less than $100.00. (3) For a third offense committed within one year of conviction for a second offense for a motorized cart or LSMV, the penalty will be determined following the provisions of section 1-12 of this Code. In addition the registered owner's LSMV registration (if public conveyance for hire) shall be revoked. The registered owner or family member cannot thereafter register a LSMV (for public conveyance for hire) for use in the city for a period of two years following the third conviction. (4) Multiple offenses within the first offense will be fined as a first offense. Multiple offenses within the second offense will be fined as a second offense. Multiple offenses within third or subsequent offenses will be fined per section 1-12 of this Code. (b) Any violation by an operator of a motorized cart or LSMV shall be charged against the operator according to the provisions of O.C.G.A. title 40, and this Code. Any violation by an owner of a motorized cart or LSMV shall be charged against the owner according to the provisions of O.C.G.A. title 40, and this Code. (Ord. of 3-22-04, § 1; Ord. of 4-14-08(2), § 5)

div.head: Chapter 98 - UTILITIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— The City of St. Marys Public Works Policies and Specifications Manual is compiled and published separately by the city. An official copy of such manual is on file in the city clerk's office. Charter reference— Service charges for water, sewer, sanitary and health services, § 5-107. Cross reference— Planning commission, § 2-211 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; cable communications, ch. 26; environment, ch. 46; floods, ch. 54; historical preservation, ch. 62; solid waste, ch. 78; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82; subdivisions, ch. 86; zoning, ch. 110. State Law reference— Power of city or county to provide stormwater, sewerage collection and disposal systems, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3.; dumping certain wastes in storm or sanitary sewers prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-2; Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; adoption of ordinances, rules and regulations relating to payment for street improvements and construction of water, gas and sewer connections; payment of costs of connections, O.C.G.A. § 36-39-7; city's authority to acquire, construct, extend, operate, maintain and collect fees for water and sewerage systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-5; Resource Recovery Development Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-63-1 et seq.; grants of state funds to municipal corporations for public purposes, O.C.G.A. § 36-40-20 et seq.; executions for collection of assessments for laying sewers, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-358.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 98-1. - Purpose. The city has experienced considerable growth over the past several years. In order to continue to provide water and sewer service to the citizens of the city and those individuals whose property is located outside the corporate city boundaries who formally request and are granted water and sewer service, the mayor and council of the city, in the interest of maintaining and protecting the health, sanitation, public safety and welfare of the general public, declare it to be the purpose and intent of this chapter to establish a uniform rate schedule for water, sewer and garbage service. (Ord. of 11-13-95(2), § I; Ord. of 6-24-96, § I; Ord. of 7-13-98, § I; Ord. of 6-12-00, § I; Ord. of 8-13-01, § I) Sec. 98-2. - Application for water and sewer service. (a) The consumer shall make application for water and sewer service at the city hall water department and at the same time shall make a security deposit of $100.00 and a nonrefundable $35.00 service turn on fee for water and sewer service. Failure to submit a complete application (Social Security number, date of birth, driver's license) will result in collection of a deposit in the amount of $250.00. (b) Upon the expiration of 12 months following the posting of the water and sewer security deposit, the deposit shall be returned to the applicant through a credit to the existing account provided: (i) a request for such credit is made by the applicant; and (ii) all bills rendered by the city for the 12-month period have been paid in full on a timely basis. In the event the applicant has not paid such bills on a timely basis, such applicant shall be entitled to a refund only after the expiration of 12 months from the last late payment was due and provided all payments within the ensuing 12-month period have been made in full on a timely basis. (c) In the event that a water and sewer security deposit has been refunded by the city and service is thereafter terminated for nonpayment, service may only be restored upon payment in full of the current bill. Following the expiration of 12 months, the applicant shall be entitled to a refund pursuant to the provisions of subsection (b), above. (d) A monthly base rate of $35.00 plus water and sewer usage charges, shall apply for temporary water and sewer services required for a time period of up to 30 days for uninhabited properties. Commercial businesses, such as rental management companies, real estate companies, inspection companies, etc., will be allowed to have this continuous temporary service with monthly renewals. This monthly charge shall apply up and until a service is requested to be disconnected for a period of up to 12 months. All service under the same commercial business name can be terminated for nonpayment on one account. Service may only be restored upon payment in full of all accounts. The outgoing party shall be responsible for all monthly charges plus usage until service is disconnected or a new occupant applies for service. (e) All new construction projects, residential and commercial, will be required to pay only for actual water used after a water meter has been installed until receipt of a certificate of occupancy or actual occupancy by a resident or commercial business owner. Upon receipt of a certificate of occupancy or actual occupancy of a structure, the standard water-sewer fees will apply as described in this chapter. (f) The landlord shall make application for water and sewer service at the city hall water department and at the same time shall make a security deposit of $100.00 and a one-time account establishment charge of $35.00 for water and sewer service when the account is first established. The standard water/sewer fees will apply as described in this chapter. (g) Customers whose account has a past due balance after disconnection who are referred to a collection agency or an attorney for collection shall be required to pay for postage, costs of additional notices, collection fees, court fees, and attorney fees which city is charged for any collection activity after such disconnection. (Ord. of 2-12-90(1); Ord. of 11-13-95(2), § V; Ord. of 6-24-96, § V; Ord. of 7-13-98, § V; Ord. of 6-12-00, § V; Ord. of 8-13-02, § V; Ord. of 4-25-05, § 1; Ord. of 3-12-07, § 1; Ord. of 4-9-07, §§ 1—4; Ord. of 6-11-07(4); Ord. of 4-27-09; Ord. of 3-21-11(3); Ord. of 5-2-11(3); Ord. No. 2014-043 , 9-15-14) Sec. 98-3. - City's responsibility and liability. (a) The city shall run a line from its distribution lines to the property line where the service line exists or is to be constructed, if the line runs immediately adjacent and parallel to the property to be served. (b) The basic connection shall be for a service line not exceeding 100 feet from the city's distribution lines. (c) The city may make connections to service other properties not adjacent to its lines upon payment of reasonable costs for the extensions of its distribution lines as may be required to render such service. (d) The city may install its meter or connection at or near the property line at the city's option. (e) The city reserves the right to refuse service unless the consumer's lines or pipes are installed in such a manner as to prevent cross-connections of backflow. (f) Under normal conditions, the consumer will be notified of any anticipated interruptions of service by the city. (g) The city shall run a line from its collection line to the property line where the service line exists if the line runs immediately adjacent and parallel to the property to be served. The basic connection fee shall be for a service line not exceeding 100 feet from the city's collection lines. (h) The city may make connections to service other properties not adjacent to its lines upon payment of reasonable costs for extensions of its collection lines as may be required to render such service. (Ord. of 2-12-90(1); Ord. of 11-13-95(2), § V; Ord. of 6-24-96, § V; Ord. of 7-13-98, § V; Ord. of 6-12-00, § V; Ord. of 8-13-02, § V) Sec. 98-4. - Consumer's responsibility and liability. (a) Water furnished by the city shall be used for consumption by the consumer, and employees only. The consumer shall not sell water to any other person or permit any other person to use said water. Disregard for this rule shall be sufficient cause for refusal and/or discontinuance of service. (b) When a meter or meter box has been placed for service, it must be unobstructed and accessible at all times to the meter reader. (c) The consumer shall furnish and maintain a private cut-off valve on the consumer's side of the meter. (d) The consumer's piping and apparatus shall be installed and maintained by the consumer at the consumer's expense, in a safe and efficient manner, and in accordance with the sanitary regulations of the state health department. (e) In order to be received as a customer and entitled to receive water from the city's water system, all applicants must offer proof that any private wells located on their property are not physically connected to the lines of the city's water system. All applicants by becoming consumers of the city shall agree that so long as they continue to be consumers of the city they will not permit the connection of any private wells on their property to the city's water system. (f) Subject to the provisions of subsection (h) sanitary sewer service furnished by the city shall not be for wastewater generated only by the city water system. With the exception of situations as set forth in subsection (h), no wastewater from private wells, storm drains, roof drains, or similar sources shall be discharged into the system. (g) The consumer's sewer piping and apparatus shall be installed and maintained at the consumer's expense. All contractors or plumbers installing water/sewer system service lines shall be registered at city hall and approved by the city. All such connections and service line work shall be done in accordance with city specifications, and all work shall be inspected and approved by the city prior to the piping being connected. (h) In the event that water service is not reasonably available, in the determination of the city manager, upon written recommendation of the public works director, the requirement of subsection (f) may be waived by the city. If such a waiver is granted, the consumer shall be required within six months of availability of sewer service to connect to the city's sewer lines upon payment of the tap fee in effect at that time. (Ord. of 2-12-90(1); Ord. of 11-13-95(2), § V; Ord. of 6-24-96, § V; Ord. of 7-13-98, § V; Ord. of 6-12-00, § V; Ord. of 8-13-01, § V; Ord. of 1-12-01, §§ 1, 2) Sec. 98-5. - Access to premises and extensions of system. (a) Duly authorized agents of the city shall have access at all hours to the premises of the consumer for the purpose of installing or removing city property, inspecting piping, reading and testing meters, or for any other purpose in connection with the water service and it facilities. (b) Extensions to the system shall be made only when the consumer shall grant or convey, or shall cause to be granted or conveyed, to the city a permanent easement of right-of-way across any property traversed by the water and sewer lines. (Ord. of 2-12-90(1); Ord. of 11-13-95(2), § V; Ord. of 6-24-96, § V; Ord. of 7-13-98, § V; Ord. of 6-12-00, § V; Ord. of 8-13-01, § V) Sec. 98-6. - Change of occupancy. Not less than three days' notice must be given in person or in writing, at the city hall water department of the city to discontinue water and sewer service or to change occupancy. The outgoing party shall be responsible for all water consumed up to the time of departure or the time specified for departure, whichever period is longer. If the disconnect date is disputed, the consumer must show proof of said date from another utility. The new occupant shall apply for service before occupying the premises. Failure to do so will result in disconnection of service until said deposits are paid, and will make him/her liable for paying for all the water consumed since the last meter reading. (Ord. of 2-12-90(1); Ord. of 11-13-95(2), § V; Ord. of 6-24-96, § V; Ord. of 7-13-98, § V; Ord. of 6-12-00, § V; Ord. of 8-13-01, § V) Sec. 98-7. - Meter reading; billings; collections. (a) Bills to customers for water and sewer service shall be mailed out on such day or days of each month as may be determined as desirable by the city. Bills must be paid by 5:00 p.m. on the due date at the water department of the city to avoid late charges. Payments may also be mailed to the city hall water department; however, we do not check postmarks on payments received by mail. Failure to receive bills shall not prevent such bills from becoming delinquent, nor relieve the consumer from payment of same. The failure of water and/or sewer users to pay charges duly imposed shall result in the automatic imposition of the following penalties: (1) Bills must be paid by 5:00 p.m. on the due date. Nonpayment of bill by this time shall be subject to a penalty of ten percent of the delinquent account. (2) Nonpayment within 30 days from the due date will result in the water being shut off from the water user's property. (3) Nonpayment for 40 days after original due date will allow the city, in addition to all other rights and remedies, to terminate agreement, and in such event, the customer shall not be entitled to receive, nor the city obligated to supply, any water under this agreement. (b) Service disconnected for nonpayment of bills will be restored only after bills are paid in full, and any additional security deposit that may be required. A service charge of $30.00 will be applied to each account if it appears on the disconnect list. Water meters may be turned off or on by a city employee only, there is a fine of $100.00 to any individual or company that tampers with the meter. When a tamper fee is determined by a city employee, the fee shall be paid before water is restored. (c) When consumers have paid by check for services, and the check has been returned by the bank for insufficient funds, a $30.00 service charge will be added to the total due. If there was a bank error, upon notification from the bank in writing, the NSF fee will be waived. All NSF checks must be picked up and replaced with cash or a money order. We will not send an NSF check back through the bank for a second approval. If the NSF check was for the customer's security deposit, the water will be disconnected. (Ord. of 2-12-90(1); Ord. of 11-13-95(2), § V; Ord. of 6-24-96, § V; Ord. of 7-13-98, § V; Ord. of 8-24-99, § 1; Ord. of 6-12-00, § V; Ord. of 8-13-01, § V; Ord. of 6-11-07(4); Ord. of 2-11-08, § 1; Ord. of 4-27-09) Sec. 98-8. - Suspension of service. (a) When water and sewer is discontinued and all bills are paid, the security deposit shall be refunded to the consumer by the city. (b) Upon discontinuance of service for nonpayment of bills, the security deposit may be applied by the city toward settlement of the account. Any balance will be refunded to the consumer; however, if the security deposit is insufficient to cover the bill, the city may proceed to collect the balance in the usual way provided by the law for collection of debts. (c) The city reserves the right to discontinue its service without notice for the following additional reasons: (1) To prevent fraud or abuse. (2) Consumer's willful disregard of the city's rules. (3) Emergency repairs. (4) Legal processes. (5) Direction of public authorities. (6) Insufficiency of water supply due to circumstances beyond the city's control. (7) Strike, riot, fire, flood, hurricane, unavoidable accidents. (8) Incomplete water/sewer application or tap application. (9) Nonsufficient funds (NSF) check given. (Ord. of 2-12-90(1); Ord. of 11-13-95(2), § V; Ord. of 6-24-96, § V; Ord. of 7-13-98, § V; Ord. of 6-12-00, § V; Ord. of 8-13-01, § V) Sec. 98-9. - Transfers. (a) There is a transfer fee of $30.00 for transferring from one address to another within the city's water system. This will be added to the consumer's bill at the time the transfer occurs. Any utility bills that are due must be paid in full before service will be transferred. (b) Upon the disconnection of an account that has a landlord agreement; the account will be transferred immediately into the name of the landlord. All monthly charges will apply per section 98-53. (Ord. of 11-13-95(2), § V; Ord. of 6-24-96, § V; Ord. of 7-13-98, § V; Ord. of 6-12-00, § V; Ord. of 8-13-01, § V; Ord. of 6-11-07(4); Ord. of 4-27-09; Ord. of 5-2-11(3)) Sec. 98-10. - Complaints, adjustments. If the consumer believes his/her bill to be in error, he/she shall present his/her claim, in person, at the city hall water department, before the bill becomes delinquent. Such claim, if made after the bill becomes delinquent, shall not be effective in preventing discontinuance of service as provided in this article. The consumer must pay such bill under protest although said payment shall not prejudice his claim. (1) The city will make a special water meter reading at the request of the consumer for a fee of $25.00; provided, however, that if such a special reading discloses that the meter was over-read, no charge will be made.
